questions.text: What is the incidence of Barrett esophagus in patients with prolonged GERD?
questions.solution:
Barrett esophagus :- it's a complication of chronic GERD

  • Intestinal metaplasia within the esophageal squamous mucosa
  • Associated with an increased risk of cancer.
  • 10% of individuals with symptomatic GERD (choice A) and up to 2% of the general population.
  • Most common in white males
  • Age :- between 40 and 60 years.
  • Subclassified as long segment (≥3 cm), or short segment (<3 cm). Patients with short-segment disease may not experience GERD symptoms and are at lower risk of developing dysplasia or carcinoma compared to long segment disease.
  • Microscopically,
    • Intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.
    • GOBLET CELLS are diagnostic.
    • Non-goblet columnar cells, such as gastric-type foveolar cells, may also be present,
    • Dysplasia is classified as low grade or high grade.
      • Both grades show - Atypical mitoses, nuclear hyperchromasia, irregularly clumped chromatin, increased nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio, and failure of epithelial cells to mature as they migrate to the esophageal surface.
      • Dysplastic glands display budding, irregular shapes, and cellular crowding.
      • High-grade dysplasia exhibits more severe cytologic and architectural changes than low-grade dysplasia.
      • With progression, epithelial cells may invade the lamina propria, a feature that defines progression to intramucosal carcinoma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Barrett's esophagus is Intestinal-type metaplasia seen as replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells

questions.text: Genetic syndromes associated with GISTs include all, EXCEPT:-
questions.solution:
GISTs may present in the form of multiple tumors in the following situations:-

  1. Neurofibromatosis type 1 (von Recklinghausen disease)
  2. Carney triad
  3. Associated with paraganglioma but different from Carney triad (Carney-Stratakis syndrome)
  4. As a familial syndrome, associated with germline mutations of KIT and with small intestinal neuronal dysplasia.

GIST can also appear as multiple tumors in the absence of any of these conditions.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Genetic syndromes associated with GIST include:

questions.text: A 12 years old child had mild abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, fatigue and loss of appetite since last one week. He had undergone appendicectomy and the gross and morphological findings are shown below. Which of the following organism could be responsible?
questions.solution:
• ENTEROBIUS VERMICULARIS (also known as PINWORMS (choice B) or OXYURIASIS) is found in 0.6%-13% of resected appendices.
  • Children and adolescents have the highest prevalence of infection.
  • Pinworms are more commonly seen in otherwise normal appendices
  • the ability of the parasite to cause mucosal damage and appendiceal inflammation remains controversial.
  • Both worms and eggs can also fill and obstruct the lumen, causing inflammation similar to that caused by fecaliths.

SCHISTOSOMIASIS (Choice A) :-

  • STRONGYLOIDIASIS STERCORALIS:- (choice C)
  • diffuse eosinophilic and/or mixed eosinophilic and neutrophilic infiltrate or by the presence of granulomas with necrotic centers and an associated eosinophilic infiltrate.
  • The parasites are found only exceptionally within the granulomas, but characteristic larvae and worms with sharply pointed tails may be found within the appendiceal crypts, similar to the remainder of the GI tract.
  • Cryptosporidium, most often seen in immunocompromised patients ; and nematodes such as Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworms) (choice D) and Trichuris species (whipworms).

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Pinworm infestation can involve the appendix, causing symptoms mimicking acute appendicitis. Histologically, worms and eggs may be found in the lumen or wall of the appendix. It is usually asymptomatic but may contribute to inflammation or obstruction in rare cases.

choices.text: Loss of Chloride, bicarbonate and sodium from intestinal lumen and causes massive diarrhea
Hemalgutinin is important for bacterial detachment into the stool
Increase in cyclic adenosine monophosphate (CAMP) opens the cystic fibrosis conductance regulator (CFTR), which releases Chloride

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding cholera?
questions.solution:
CHOLERA :-

Reservoir :- Shellfish

Transmission :- Fecal-oral, water

Affected GI sites :- small intestine

Symptoms :- severe watery diarrhea

Complication :- Dehydration, electrolyte imbalance

Pathogenesis of Cholera:-

  • Severe diarrhea is caused by the toxin released by the bacteria. Vibrio organisms are noninvasive and remain within the intestinal lumen. Proteins involved in motility and attachment are necessary for efficient colonization. Hemagglutinin, a metalloproteinase, is important for bacterial detachment and shedding into the stool, which is key to dissemination. (Choice B)
  • Increase in intracellular cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) opens the cystic fibrosis conductance regulator (CFTR), which releases chloride ions into the lumen. (Choice C)
    • Chloride and sodium absorption are also inhibited by cAMP.
    • The resulting ACCUMULATION of chloride, bicarbonate, and sodium (choice A) within the intestinal lumen creates an osmotic force that draws water into the lumen and causes massive diarrhea.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Cholera causes Increase in intracellular cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) opens the cystic fibrosis conductance regulator (CFTR), which releases chloride ions into the lumen

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presents with general discomfort and increasing tightness in the skin of her face. She reports intermittent pain in the tips of her fingers when exposed to the Cold. Physical examination shows 'stone facies' and edema Of the fingers and hands. Serologic tests for antinuclear and Anti-Scl-70 antibodies are both positive. Which of the following gastrointestinal manifestations is expected in this Patient?
questions.solution:
This patient exhibits signs of SCLERODERMA (progressive systemic sclerosis), which is characterized by vasculopathy and excessive collage deposition in The skin and internal organs.

  • Symptoms :- Intermittent episodes of ischemia of the fingers, marked by pallor, paresthesias, and pain (Raynaud phenomenon).
  • Anti-Scl-7 Antibodies to nuclear topoisomerase are virtually specific for This autoimmune disease.
  • Affected GI sites :- any portion of the gastrointestinal tract, although esophageal dysfunction is the most common complication.
  • The disease affects principally the lower esophageal sphincter, Which may become so impaired that the lower esophagus and Upper stomach are no longer distinct functional entities.
  • In Some affected patients, there may be a lack of peristalsis in the Entire esophagus.
  • The other choices are not associated with Scleroderma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Scleroderma is characterised by esophageal dysphagia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with a 2-month history of abdominal discomfort and dark stools. Physical examination shows pallor but no evidence of jaundice. Peripheral smear shows microcytic, hypochromic anemia, with a hemoglobin level of 6.7 g/dL. A barium swallow radiograph reveals a leather bottle appearance of the stomach. Gross and microscopic examination are given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Gastric adenocarcinoma (diffuse type) - Linitis plastica.

  • Diffuse adenocarcinoma constitutes 10% of all stomach cancers.
  • Gross :- No true tumor mass, the wall of the stomach gets thickened and firm.
  • Radiological findings :- 'leather bottle' appearance.
    • When the entire stomach is involved, the term LINITIS PLASTICA is applied.
  • Microscopic findings :-
    • The invading tumor cells induce extensive fibrosis in the submucosa and muscularis of the stomach wall.
    • SIGNET RING CELLS are so named because intracellular mucin displaces the nuclei to the periphery of the tumor cells.
  • Metastasis :- Gastric carcinomas typically metastasize to regional lymph nodes and the liver.
  • Poor prognosis
  • The other choices do not show the characteristic morphologic appearance of linitis plastica and generally do not exhibit signet ring cells. (Choice A, B, C)

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Linitis plastica is a rare form of diffuse gastric cancer characterized by infiltration of the stomach wall by malignant cells, leading to a thickened and rigid stomach with loss of its distensibility. It is also called "leather bottle stomach" due to its characteristic gross appearance.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman complains of increasing abdominal girth of 5 weeks in duration. Physical examination discloses ascites, and cytologic examination of the fluid reveals malignant cells. Exploratory laparotomy shows multiple tumor nodules on the serosal surface of the intestines. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Metastatic carcinoma

  • Metastatic carcinoma is by far the most common malignant disorder affecting the peritoneum.
  • Ovarian, gastric, and pancreatic carcinomas are particularly likely to seed the peritoneum, but any intra-abdominal carcinoma can spread to the peritoneum.
  • Metastatic carcinoma to the abdomen presents in the form of multiple serosal nodules and ascites fluid that contains malignant cells.
  • Metastases frequently involve the small bowel, often in the form of multiple polypoid masses.
  • The lesions may result in obstruction or perforation.
  • The most common types of tumor metastasizing to the small bowel are MALIGNANT MELANOMA. (which must be distinguished from the rare primary melanoma of small bowel, and carcinomas from lung, breast, and ovary, and choriocarcinoma)
    • Melanoma can present radiographically as intraluminal masses, ulcerated lesions, diffuse infiltration of the wall, or implants.
    • Patients with multiple metastases from melanoma usually die within 1 year following palliative surgery, but an occasional long-term survivor will be found among those with isolated metastases.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Metastatic carcinoma is by far the most common malignant disorder affecting the peritoneum.

questions.text: A 56 year-old woman presents with sudden attacks of wheezing, shortness of breath, and episodic hot flashes. She also reports abdominal cramps and diarrhea. Physical examination Shows facial redness, pitting edema of the lower legs, and a murmur of tricuspid regurgitation. A 24-hour urine specimen contains elevated levels of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA). A CT scan of the abdomen demonstrates multiple 1- to 1.5 cm nodules in distal ileum. A small bowel resection is performed (shown in the gross and microscopic image). Which of the following is the Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CARCINOID TUMOR

  • Low-grade malignant neoplasms
  • Most are located in the ileum (including Meckel diverticulum), followed the jejunum and distal duodenum.
  • WNETs tumors of the small bowel are multiple in 15%-35% of the cases.
  • They are most commonly located in the submucosa of the intestines (appendix, terminal ileum, and rectum).
  • Gross :-
  • Microscopy :- Neuroendocrine cells, which usually show considerable nuclear uniformity.
  • Carcinoids are distinguished from intestinal carcinomas based on their location, histologic features, malignant potential, endocrine activity, and clinical features.
  • Carcinoid syndrome is a systemic paraneoplastic disease caused by the release of hormones from carcinoid tumors into venous blood.
  • Clinical features :- flushing, bronchial wheezing, watery diarrhea, and abdominal colic (caused by the Release of serotonin, bradykinin, and histamine)
  • The other choices are not associated with secretion of 5-HIAA Acid or other neuroendocrine peptides.
  • Histologically, gastric MALToma takes the form of a dense lymphocytic infiltrate in the lamina propria. The neoplastic lymphocytes infiltrate gastric glands to create diagnostic lymphoepithelial lesions. (choice C) (which is not the picture of this case)
  • Peutz jeghers syndrome :- (choice D)
  • The polyps are large and pedunculated with a lobulated contour.
  • Histologic examination demonstrates a characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Key Takeaways: Carcinoid tumors are slow-growing neuroendocrine tumors commonly arising in the gastrointestinal tract (especially the small intestine) and bronchial tree. They secrete serotonin and other vasoactive substances, potentially leading to carcinoid syndrome (flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and right-sided valvular heart disease) if liver metastases bypass hepatic metabolism. Diagnosis involves chromogranin A levels, urinary 5-HIAA, and imaging, while management includes surgical resection and somatostatin analogs like octreotide.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman suffers a massive stroke and expires. The stomach at autopsy is shown in the image. Prior to her death, this patient would most likely have exhibited which of the following?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is PEPTIC ULCER DISEASE.

  • Gross:- Peptic ulcers appear as punched out, rounded ulcers.
  • The given image shows typical gross appearance of chronic peptic ulcer of the stomach. Sharply delineated chronic peptic ulcer with converging folds of mucosa. The upper bed is covered by fibropurulent exudate.
  • Erosion through arteries causes BLEEDING and iron-deficiency anemia.
  • Melena refers to black, tarry stools composed largely Of blood from the upper digestive tract that has been processed by the action of gastric juices.
  • Melena is commonly seen in patients who suffer from chronic peptic ulcer disease.
  • Unlike duodenal ulcers, most patients with gastric ulcers secrete normal or decreased amounts of gastric acid (see choice B).

Key Takeaways: Peptic ulcers are mucosal defects in the stomach or duodenum caused by an imbalance between aggressive factors (e.g., gastric acid, pepsin, H. pylori infection, NSAIDs) and protective mechanisms (e.g., mucus, bicarbonate). Symptoms include epigastric pain, often related to meals. Complications include bleeding, perforation, and gastric outlet obstruction. Diagnosis involves endoscopy and H. pylori testing, while treatment includes proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), H. pylori eradication, and lifestyle modifications.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT associated with autoimmune gastritis?
questions.solution:
Intestinal metaplasia seen in autoimmune gastritis can undergo dysplasia and progress to adenocarcinoma.

  • Spares the antrum
  • Associated with marked hypergastrinemia.
  • It accounts for less than 10% of cases of chronic gastritis
  • It is characterized by:
    • Antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor that can be detected in serum and gastric secretions
    • Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration
    • Endocrine cell hyperplasia
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency
    • Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria)
  • The median age at diagnosis is 60.
  • F>M
  • Pernicious anemia and autoimmune atrophic gastritis are associated with :-
    • Hashimoto's Thyroiditis
    • Hypothyroidism
    • Myasthenia gravis
    • Other autoimmune disorders ( which tend to run together) including Sjogren disease
    • Type 1 Diabetes mellitus
    • Adrenal insufficiency. (Addison's disease)

Autoimmune gastritis is NOT reversed with gluten restriction.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Autoimmune gastritis is a chronic inflammatory condition caused by autoantibodies targeting parietal cells and intrinsic factor, leading to gastric atrophy, hypochlorhydria, and vitamin B12 deficiency (pernicious anemia). It predominantly affects the gastric body and fundus and is associated with an increased risk of gastric neuroendocrine tumors and adenocarcinoma. Diagnosis is made through serology (anti-parietal cell and intrinsic factor antibodies), endoscopy, and biopsy.

questions.text: Gastrin-secreting tumors and elevated gastrin levels are characteristic findings of which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
• Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by massive acid secretion and severe peptic ulcer disease, due to hypergastrinemia secondary to gastrinoma.
  • Patients present with distal duodenal ulcers, heartburn, and diarrhea. Elevated gastrin levels are found in the patients.
  • Gross :- massive hypertrophy of gastric rugal folds in the gastric body and fundus.
  • Light microscopy :- Shows parietal cell hypertrophy and hyperplasia with atrophy of overlying foveolar epithelium.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterized by massive acid secretion and severe peptic ulcer disease, due to hypergastrinemia secondary to gastrinoma.

choices.text: Dense accumulation of foamy macrophages in the lamina propria
Expanded lamina propria with increased plasma cells

questions.text: Which of the following microscopic features is NOT associated with celiac disease?
questions.solution:
Biopsy specimens from the second portion of the duodenum or proximal jejunum (highest concentrations of dietary gluten) :-

  • Increased numbers of intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes (intraepithelial lymphocytosis) (choice B)
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Villous atrophy or blunting (choice D)
  • Increased numbers of plasma cells, mast cells, and eosinophils, especially within the upper part of the lamina propria.
  • This loss of mucosal and brush-border surface area contributes to malabsorption.
  • intraepithelial lymphocytosis and villous atrophy are not specific for celiac disease and can be present in other diseases, including viral enteritis.
  • The combination of HISTOLOGY AND SEROLOGY therefore is most specific for diagnosis of celiac disease.

Plasma cells that are producing the IgA antibodies causing tissue damage are present in the expanded lamina propria (choice C) and villous blunting (choice D) occurs as the crypt zone falls behind the race of loss of damaged surface enterocytes.

Key Takeaways:

Histological Findings in Celiac Disease:

  1. Villous Atrophy: Partial to complete flattening of intestinal villi.
  2. Crypt Hyperplasia: Elongation and deepening of the crypts of Lieberkuhn.
  3. Increased Intraepithelial Lymphocytes (IELs): More than 25-30 lymphocytes per 100 enterocytes.
  4. Lamina Propria Inflammation: Presence of plasma cells, lymphocytes, and eosinophils.
  5. Mucosal Scalloping (Gross): Visualized during endoscopy as a hallmark feature in severe cases.

questions.text: What is the most likely molecular alteration associated with the familiar form of the lesion in the following gastric biopsy?
questions.solution:
• GASTRIC ADENOCARCINOMA incidence varies markedly with geography.
  • Two types:-
    1. GASTRIC TUMORS - INTESTINAL TYPE :-
      • Form bulky tumors and may be ulcerated,
    2. GASTRIC TUMORS - DIFFUSE TYPE :-
      • Composed of signet-ring cells pattern
      • Thicken the gastric wall without forming a discrete mass.
  • The above two images are of showing both varieties; intestinal-type and diffuse type.
  • Familial gastric cancer is strongly associated with germline loss-of-function mutations in the tumor suppressor gene CDH1, which encodes the cell adhesion protein E-cadherin.
  • Loss-of-function mutations in CDH1 are also present in about 50% of sporadic diffuse gastric tumors, while E-cadherin expression is drastically decreased in the remainder of diffuse tumors, often by hypermethylation and silencing of the CDH1 promoter.

Key Takeaways: E-cadherin loss is a key step in the development of diffuse gastric cancer. CDH1 mutations are also common in sporadic and familial lobular carcinoma of the breast, which, like diffuse gastric cancer (see later), tends to infiltrate as single cells.

questions.text: Which syndrome is associated with adenomatous colon polyps and medulloblastoma?
questions.solution:
Turcot syndrome describes a polyposis syndrome associated with brain tumors.

  • There are 2 forms of this syndrome.
    1. The first type is FAP associated with mutations in the APC gene, which most often has an associated medulloblastoma; however, astrocytomas and ependymomas have been reported.
    2. The second type is associated with lynch syndrome (HNPCC) and mutations in the MLHl or MSH2 pathways and is associated glioblastoma multiforme.

KEY TAKEAWAYS:

Turcot syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the association of colorectal polyps or colorectal cancer with primary brain tumors. It has two main variants:

  1. APC-Associated Variant:
    • Caused by mutations in the APC
    • Associated with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and medulloblastomas.
  2. MutYH-Associated Variant:
    • Caused by mutations in MutYH
    • Associated with fewer colorectal polyps and glioblastomas.

Clinical Features:

  • Gastrointestinal: Multiple adenomatous polyps, increased risk of colorectal cancer.
  • Neurological: Brain tumors such as medulloblastoma or glioblastoma.

questions.text: This gastric lesion pictured below is best characterized as which of the following?
questions.solution:
The images demonstrate a polypoid lesion within the antrum.

  • These lesions are of themselves considered nonneoplastic (regenerative polyps) in me setting of inflammatory conditions.
  • It demonstrates hyperplastic changes with elongated foveolae with intraluminal infolding and cystic dilation.
  • Microscopy :-
    • The glands are lined by mature gastric mucin cells
    • Edematous stroma
    • Intestinal metaplasia
  • These lesions are of themselves considered nonneoplastic (regenerative polyps) in me setting of inflammatory conditions.
  • However, these lesions can be associated with conditions that often lead to dysplasia ( often p53+) and carcinoma.
  • Hyperplastic polyps can be seen in up to 20% of patients with gastric cancer.
